conversation.text: This is how to make Candied Jujubes. Would you like to begin?
Yes, what is the first step?
First you must boil water, sugar and cornstarch
evidence: Boil the water, sugar, and cornstarch

conversation.text: How much water, sugar and cornstarch do I need?
3 1/3 cups cold water, 3 2/3 cups sugar and 2 tsp cornstarch. Use a medium to medium-high heat to dissolve dry ingredients
evidence: 3⅓ cups (780 milliliters) of cold water
Add 3⅔ cups (825 grams) of sugar
2 teaspoons of cornstarch

conversation.text: Okay, what should I do once the ingredients are dissolved?
Now wash and dry 2 lbs dried jujubes. Prick each one with a fork several times.
evidence: Wash and dry 2 pounds (907 grams) of dried jujubes
Prick each one with a fork a few times

conversation.text: Why must I prick each one with a fork?
They will absorb the sugar water more effectively.
evidence: This will make it easier for them to absorb the water and sugar.

conversation.text: Okay, what should I do next?
Now wait for the jujubes in the saucepan to cool to room temperature. Then cover the pan with a lid and chill in the fridge overnight
evidence: Let the mixture reach room temperature first
Cover the saucepan with a lid, then store it in the fridge overnight

conversation.text: Alright, once the jujubes have cooled what should I do?
Now it is time to reheat the jujubes
evidence: Reheat the jujubes

conversation.text: Should I reheat them in the saucepan with the sugar water?
Correct. Place the pan on the stove, take off the lid and bring to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. Once they begin boiling reduce the heat to let them simmer
evidence: Place the saucepan on the stove and remove the lid
Bring the mixture to a boil over medium to medium-high heat
As soon as it is boiling, reduce the heat to a simmer

conversation.text: How long should I let them simmer?
The jujubes should simmer for 30 minutes without the lid on
evidence: Allow it to cook, uncovered, for 30 minutes.

conversation.text: What should I do once the jujubes have simmered?
Now it is time to remove the jujubes from the saucepan
evidence: Remove the jujubes from the pot

conversation.text: What should I use to remove the jujubes? Do I need to pour them with the water?
Use a slotted spoon to remove the jujubes
evidence: using a slotted spoon

conversation.text: Where should I put the jujubes?
Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil and set out the jujubes on it
evidence: Set them aside on rimmed baking sheets lined with aluminum foil

conversation.text: How should the jujubes be arranged on the sheet? Should they be close together or spread apart?
The jujubes should be spread quite far apart so they can dry properly. More than one baking sheet can be used.
evidence: Don't try to cram them together on one sheet, or they won't dry properly

conversation.text: Should I dispose of the sugar syrup or can it be used for something else?
The syrup can be boiled down to 1 1/3 cups and put into a glass bottle and stored in the fridge. It can then be used as syrup on pancakes or waffles.
evidence: Don't throw the syrup away!
Keep boiling it until it reduces to 1⅓ cups
Pour it into a glass bottle and use it as a syrup on pancakes and waffles. Store it in the fridge.

conversation.text: What should I do with the jujubes now? Where should I store them?
The jujubes now need to be dried in the oven.
evidence: Dry the jujubes in a warm oven.

conversation.text: How hot should the oven be?
The oven should be preheated to 275 F or 135 C. The jujubes should be turned every so often to ensure the other side dries.
evidence: Preheat your oven to 275°F (135°C).

conversation.text: How long should I keep the jujubes in the oven?
The jujubes should be in the oven for 2 to 5 hours
evidence: let the jujubes dry for 2 to 5 hours

conversation.text: What should the jujubes look like when they are oven dried?
The jujubes should look dry, like dates. The syrup will make them sticky but they should not be wet.
evidence: They are ready when they are dry like dates.

conversation.text: Are there any further steps?
No, the jujubes are finished when they are removed from the oven.
Okay. The jujubes are finished.
Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.
Thank you for helping me to make candied jujubes

procedure.summary: Boil the water, sugar, and cornstarch.
procedure.description: Fill a large saucepan with 3⅓ cups (780 milliliters) of cold water. Add 3⅔ cups (825 grams) of sugar, and 2 teaspoons of cornstarch. Bring the water to a boil over medium to medium-high heat to dissolve the sugar and cornstarch.
Wash and dry 2 pounds (907 grams) of dried jujubes. Prick each one with a fork a few times. This will make it easier for them to absorb the water and sugar.

procedure.summary: Add the jujubes to the saucepan.
procedure.description: Reduce the heat to a simmer over medium-low to low heat. Let them cook, uncovered, for 30 minutes. Ever so often, give the mixture a stir.

procedure.summary: Let them cool, then cover and chill them in the fridge overnight.
procedure.description: Let the mixture reach room temperature first. Cover the saucepan with a lid, then store it in the fridge overnight.

Place the saucepan on the stove and remove the lid. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. As soon as it is boiling, reduce the heat to a simmer. Allow it to cook, uncovered, for 30 minutes.

procedure.summary: Remove the jujubes from the pot using a slotted spoon.
procedure.description: Set them aside on rimmed baking sheets lined with aluminum foil. Don't try to cram them together on one sheet, or they won't dry properly. Don't throw the syrup away! Keep boiling it until it reduces to 1⅓ cups (320 milliliters). Pour it into a glass bottle and use it as a syrup on pancakes and waffles. Store it in the fridge.

procedure.summary: Dry the jujubes in a warm oven.
procedure.description: Preheat your oven to 275°F (135°C). Place the baking sheets into the oven, and let the jujubes dry for 2 to 5 hours. Every so often, turn them over so that the other side dries. They are ready when they are dry like dates.
